snippet: Despite the diversity of New York’s population, the proportion of non-Hispanic black residents on the Upper East Side has remained exceedingly low for decades.
abstract: Elizabeth A Harris The Appraisal column on the proportion of non-Hispanic black residents on the Upper East Side of New York, which remains exceedingly low, despite the diversity of the city's population; only 2.7 percent of the neighborhood's residents are black, rising from 2.1 percent in 1990; proportion of white residents has held fairly stable, dropping to 81 percent from 88.6 percent.
lead_paragraph: Despite the diversity of New York’s population, the proportion of non-Hispanic black residents on the Upper East Side has remained exceedingly low for decades.

headline.seo: On Upper East Side, Racial Disparity Remains
headline.main: A Stubborn Racial Disparity in Who Calls the Upper East Side Home
headline.print_headline: A Stubborn Racial Disparity in Who Calls the Upper East Side Home
